EVOLUTION 

Organic evolution is the series of gradual changes which living organisms had undergone in response to changes in an environment since the beginning of time.

Many plants and animals have become extinct with the waning of time. Dinosaurs became extinct thousands of years back. Some other organisms are still surviving by slowly adapting them with little changes.

Lamarck’s theory is called the theory of use and disuse

His theory of evolution is based on the principle that acquired traits or physical changes in organisms during their lifetime-such as greater development of an organ or a part through use and disuse-could be transmitted to their offspring. Lamarck’s theory also states that great changes in environment result in corresponding changes in species. 

Darwin’s theory is the theory of natural selection

It states that species produce offspring in large number which result in competition among them which result in the survival of the fittest.

Convergent evolution means the process whereby organisms that are not closely related, independently evolve similar traits or structures as a result of having to adapt to similar environments or ecological niches. These structures perform the same function but have different structural organization. Examples of convergent evolution are wings of butterflies and birds, fins of fishes and whales’ flippers.

Contrarily, divergent evolution means the evolutionary process whereby groups from the same common ancestor evolve and accumulate differences, resulting in the formation of new species, which might be as a result of the availability of new niche or changes in the environment. Example can be found in comparing turtle and tortoise. 

A Diastema is a wide gap that separates rows of teeth mostly in herbivore. In plant-eating mammals like goat, the diastema separates the biting teeth at the front of the jaw, from the chewing teeth at the rear. This is an evolution change, the herbivores during evolution, stopped consuming meat and depending entirely on plants for their energy requirements. Since, they no longer require the services of canine tooth for piercing and tearing into meat or flesh.

 

UNN PUTME Examples

1. The flippers of whale and the fins of a fish are examples of 

A. coevolution B. convergent evolution C. divergent evolution D. continuous evolution 

(B. Convergent evolution means the process whereby organisms that are not closely related, independently evolve similar traits or structures as a result of having to adapt to similar environments or ecological niches. These structures perform the same function but have different structural organization. Examples of convergent evolution are wings of butterflies and birds, fins of fishes and whales’ flippers, 2019/2020, no 4)

 

2. The presence of a diastema in the jaw bone indicates that the mammal lacks the teeth suitable for 

A. tearing B. chewing C. cutting D. chewing and tearing 

(A. A Diastema is a wide gap that separates rows of teeth mostly in herbivore. This is an evolution change, the herbivores during evolution, stopped consuming meat and depending entirely on plants for their energy requirements, 2019/2020, no 7)

 

3. The use and disuse of the body parts and the inheritance of acquired traits were used to explain 

A, Darwin’s theory B. Larmarck’s theory C. Genetic drift D. Gene flow

(B. Lamarck’s theory is called the theory of use and disuse. His theory of evolution is based on the principle that acquired traits or physical changes in organisms during their lifetime-such as greater development of an organ or a part through use and disuse-could be transmitted to their offspring, 2019/2020, no 10)

 

JAMB Examples

1. Which of the following theories was NOT considered by Darwin in his evolutionary theory?

A. Variation B. Survival of the fittest C. Use and disuse D. Competition

(A. Use and disuse)

 

2. The fallacy in Lamarck's evolutionary theory was the assumption that

A. traits are acquired through disuse of body parts B. acquired traits are heritable C. acquired traits are seldom formed D. traits are acquired through the use of body parts

(A. traits are acquired through disuse of body parts)

 

3. From his study of Galapagos finches, Darwin derived his theory of evolution from

A. comparative anatomy B. comparative physiology C. fossil remains D. comparative embryology

(A. comparative anatomy)

 

4. All living organisms are constantly involved in a struggle for existence. This was proposed by

A. Morgan B. Darwin C. Lamarck D. Wallace

(B. Darwin)

 

5. Adaptive radiation is illustrated in

A. modified insect mouthparts B. dentition in mammals C. wings in birds and bats D. appendages in insects

(Both A. modified insect mouthparts B. dentition in mammals)

 

6. The theory which supports the view that the large muscles developed by an athlete will be passed on to the offspring was proposed by

A. Mendel B. Darwin C. Lamark D. Pasteur

(C. Lamark)

 

7. The wings of a bat and those of a bird are examples of

A. convergent evolution B. continuous variation C. coevolution D. divergent evolution

A. convergent evolution)

 

8. All living organisms are constantly involved in a struggle for existence. This was proposed by

A. Morgan B. Darwin C. Lamarck D. Wallace

(B. Darwin)
